10870Journal of Chemical CrystallographyJ Chem Crystallogr1074-15421572-8854Springer USBostons10870-010-9731-9973110.1007/s10870-010-9731-9CommunicationSynthesis and Crystal Structure of Copper(II)-Hexafluoro-Acetylacetonate Complexes with Pyridyl-Substituted Nitronyl and Imino-Nitroxide RadicalsWangKun-Miao1DuLin1FangRui-Bing1ZhaoQi-Hua1dgrid.440773.3Key Laboratory of Medicinal Chemistry for Natural Resource, Department of Chemistry Education MinistryYunnan University650091KunmingYunnanChinaqhzhao@ynu.edu.cn4320105201040547247511220103420081122010432010© Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 20102010Abstract

A one-dimensional chain compound was formed by copper (II) hexafluoroacetylacetonate (hfac) and nitroxide radical 2-(4-pyridyl)-4,4,5,5-tetramethyl-imidazoline-1-oxyl-oxide (NITpPy). The product was structurally characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction. [Cu2(hfac)4NITpPy]n crystallizes in the monoclinic C2/c space group with a = 19.70(2), b = 16.834(19), c = 15.274(18) Å, β = 119.073, V = 4427(9) Å3, Z = 4, R = 0.0699 wR2 (all data) = 0.1752. In the compound, two different Cu(hfac)2 units are bridged by NITpPy. The nitrogen atom of pyridine ring is coordinated with Cu(II) ion to afford a three-spin complex. Cu(II) ions of Cu(hfac)2 and the oxygen atoms of nitronyl nitroxide formed weak coordination bonds with the bond length 2.495(8) Å.

Graphical Abstract

A one-dimensional chain compound [Cu2(hfac)4NITpPy]n was formed by copper (II) hexafluoroacetylacetonate (hfac) and nitroxide radical 2-(4-pyridyl)-4,4,5,5-tetramethyl-imidazoline-1-oxyl-oxide (NITpPy). In the compound, two different Cu(hfac)2 units are bridged by NITpPy forming a 1D zigzag chain with the weak coordination bond Cu–O bond length 2.495(8) Å.

KeywordsNitronyl nitroxide radicalCopper complexWeak coordinationvolume-issue-count12issue-article-count14issue-toc-levels0issue-pricelist-year2010issue-copyright-holderSpringer Science+Business Media, LLCissue-copyright-year2010article-contains-esmNoarticle-numbering-styleUnnumberedarticle-registration-date-year2010article-registration-date-month2article-registration-date-day11article-toc-levels0toc-levels0volume-typeRegularjournal-productNonStandardArchiveJournalnumbering-styleUnnumberedarticle-grants-typeRegularmetadata-grantOpenAccessabstract-grantOpenAccessbodypdf-grantRestrictedbodyhtml-grantRestrictedbibliography-grantRestrictedesm-grantOpenAccessonline-firstfalsepdf-file-referenceBodyRef/PDF/10870_2010_Article_9731.pdftarget-typeOnlinePDFissue-online-date-year2010issue-online-date-month4issue-online-date-day3issue-print-date-year2010issue-print-date-month4issue-print-date-day2issue-typeRegulararticle-typeBriefCommunicationjournal-subject-primaryChemistryjournal-subject-secondaryInorganic Chemistry journal-subject-secondaryPhysical Chemistry journal-subject-secondaryCrystallographyjournal-subject-secondaryOrganometallic Chemistry open-accessfalseIntroduction

The design and synthesis of metal-nitronyl nitroxide radical complexes is one of the most attractive fields in the molecular-based magnetic materials [1]. Following this approach many molecular-based ferromagnets have been successfully synthesized and studied such as high spin molecules [2], single-chain magnets [3], chiral molecular magnet [4] and molecule spin transition species [5]. In case of metal-nitronyl nitroxide radicals (NIT) complexes, metal part containing electron withdrawing groups was widely used e.g. M(hfac)2, due to the weak basic nature of the nitroxide moiety [6]. Recently, several Cu(hfac)2 complex with pyridyl-substituted (ortho-, para- and meta-) nitronyl nitroxide radicals have been synthesized and studied such as [Cu(hfac)2(NIToPyBr)2]2 [7], [Cu(hfac)2]4(NITmPy)2 [8], and a lot of Cu–NITpPy compounds have been reported e.g. [Cu2(pro)4(NITpPy)2] [9], Cu(NO3)2(NITpPy)2 [10] and CuI2(NITpPy)4 [11] etc., but Cu(hfac)2–NITpPy example with one-dimensional structure has not been found yet. In this paper, we report the synthesis and structural characterization of [Cu2(hfac)4(NITpPy)]n. To our knowledge, this is the first example of a copper(II)–NITpPy complex containing Cu···O weak coordination interactions.

ExperimentalMaterials

All analytical grade chemicals and solvents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. Copper(II) bishexafluoroacetylacetonate dihydrate [Cu(hfac)2·2H2O] and the nitronyl nitroxide radicals (NITpPy) were prepared and purified according to the literature methods previously described [12, 13].

Preparation of the Complex

The solution of Cu(hfac)2·2H2O (0.1 mmol) in 20 mL of boiling n-heptane was refluxed to remove hydrate water. To the resulting solution cooled to 60 °C was added 5 mL dichloromethane containing 0.1 mmol of NITpPy. The temperature of the reaction was kept at about 60 °C for 15 min, during which a dark blue precipitate appeared, which was filtered off. The filtrate was allowed to cool to room temperature. Two days later, dark blue crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were collected (yield 50%). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C32H20Cu2F24N3O10: C 32.31, H 1.69, N 3.53; found: C 32.53, H 1.78, N 3.35.

Crystal Structure Determination

The selected blue crystal with approximate dimensions of 0.41 mm × 0.29 mm × 0.14 mm was mounted on a Bruker Smart AXS CCD with a graphite monochromatic MoK α radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The intensity data were collected at 298(2) K by using a ω and π scan mode in the range of 1.69 ≤ θ ≤ 25.03° with the following index ranges: −23 ≤ h ≤ 22, −20 ≤ k ≤ 19 and 18 ≤ l ≤ 17. A total of 9654 reflections were collected and 3558 were independent (Rint = 0.1459, of which 1164 were considered as observed (I > 2σ(I)). Absorption correction was applied using SADABS program [14].The structure was solved by direct methods with SHELXS-97 [15] and refined by full-matrix least-squares calculations with SHELXL-97 [16]. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. Most of the hydrogen atoms were located at the calculated positions or found from difference Fourier maps (Table 1).

Results and Discussion

Molecular structure of 1 is shown in Fig. 1. The complex consists of neutral units Cu(hfac)2 and one NITpPy ligands. Each NITpPy radical links two different copper(II) ions through the oxygen of nitroide group and the pyridyl nitrogen to form a zigzag-like centrosymmetric one-dimensional chain. In the crystal structure of 1, there are two crystallographic independent Cu (Cu1 and Cu2) atoms in the form of Cu(hfac)2. The Cu1 atom has a five-coordinated distorted trigonal bipyramidal environment with four oxygen atoms of two hfac molecules and one pyridyl nitrogen atom. The Cu1–O2 and Cu1–O3 bond lengths are 2.051(8) and 1.945(9) Å, respectively. The Cu1–N2 bond length is 2.014(9) Å. The pyridine ring of nitronyl nitroxide has a dihedral angle of 71.5° with the average plane consisting of equatorial oxygen atoms of the hfac ligands and the Cu1 atom, while the dihedral angle between the ONCNO five member ring is 32.0(4)°. As mentioned above, there is another Cu atom in the unit, which is referred as Cu′(hfac)2. It is noticed that weak coordination bonds are formed between the Cu(II) of Cu(hfac)2 and the oxygen atoms of nitronyl nitroxide with the oxygen atoms occupying the apical positions. The weak Cu2–O1 bond length is 2.50(2) Å and the bond angle of N1–O1–Cu2 is 166(2)°. Here, we could consider NITpPy as a bidentate bridged two different Cu(hfac)2 units. Considering the weak coordination, the coordination environment about the Cu2 ion of Cu′(hfac)2 exhibits a distorted octahedral coordination geometry with O4#2–Cu2–O4 180.0(4)° and O4#2–Cu2–O1 91.7(4)° (#2: −x + 3, −y + 3/2, −z + 1). The two hfac ligands chelated to Cu(II) ion of Cu′(hfac)2 with the Cu2–O4 and Cu2–O5 bond distances of 1.909(5) and 1.903(5) Å, respectively. In the complex 1, Cu–Ohfac bond lengths are slightly shorter than the other copper similar complexes in the previous literature [17]. The ONCNO rings of nitronyl nitroxide are almost perpendicular to the coordinated plane of Cu(hfac)2 with the dihedral angle of 79.55°. As a result, the 1D chain structure was formed through the Cu···O weak coordination bonding and the inter-chain arrangements (Table 2, Fig. 2).

Acknowledgements

This work was financially supported by the NNSFC (No: 20761005), the Specialized Research Fund for the Doctoral Program of Higher Education (No. 20060673015).

The ONCNO rings of nitronyl nitroxide are almost perpendicular to the coordinated plane of Cu(hfac)2 with the dihedral angle of 79.55°. Abstract

A one-dimensional chain compound was formed by copper (II) hexafluoroacetylacetonate (hfac) and nitroxide radical 2-(4-pyridyl)-4,4,5,5-tetramethyl-imidazoline-1-oxyl-oxide (NITpPy). The product was structurally characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction. [Cu2(hfac)4NITpPy]n crystallizes in the monoclinic C2/c space group with a = 19.70(2), b = 16.834(19), c = 15.274(18) Å, β = 119.073, V = 4427(9) Å3, Z = 4, R = 0.0699 wR2 (all data) = 0.1752. In the compound, two different Cu(hfac)2 units are bridged by NITpPy. The nitrogen atom of pyridine ring is coordinated with Cu(II) ion to afford a three-spin complex. Cu(II) ions of Cu(hfac)2 and the oxygen atoms of nitronyl nitroxide formed weak coordination bonds with the bond length 2.495(8) Å.

Introduction

The design and synthesis of metal-nitronyl nitroxide radical complexes is one of the most attractive fields in the molecular-based magnetic materials [1]. Following this approach many molecular-based ferromagnets have been successfully synthesized and studied such as high spin molecules [2], single-chain magnets [3], chiral molecular magnet [4] and molecule spin transition species [5]. In case of metal-nitronyl nitroxide radicals (NIT) complexes, metal part containing electron withdrawing groups was widely used e.g. M(hfac)2, due to the weak basic nature of the nitroxide moiety [6]. Recently, several Cu(hfac)2 complex with pyridyl-substituted (ortho-, para- and meta-) nitronyl nitroxide radicals have been synthesized and studied such as [Cu(hfac)2(NIToPyBr)2]2 [7], [Cu(hfac)2]4(NITmPy)2 [8], and a lot of Cu-NITpPy compounds have been reported e.g. [Cu2(pro)4(NITpPy)2] [9], Cu(NO3)2(NITpPy)2 [10] and CuI2(NITpPy)4 [11] etc., but Cu(hfac)2-NITpPy example with one-dimensional structure has not been found yet. In this paper, we report the synthesis and structural characterization of [Cu2(hfac)4(NITpPy)]n. To our knowledge, this is the first example of a copper(II)-NITpPy complex containing Cu⋅⋅⋅O weak coordination interactions.

elements.content: All analytical grade chemicals and solvents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. Copper(II) bishexafluoroacetylacetonate dihydrate [Cu(hfac)2·2H2O] and the nitronyl nitroxide radicals (NITpPy) were prepared and purified according to the literature methods previously described [12, 13].
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials

All analytical grade chemicals and solvents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. Copper(II) bishexafluoroacetylacetonate dihydrate [Cu(hfac)2⋅2H2O] and the nitronyl nitroxide radicals (NITpPy) were prepared and purified according to the literature methods previously described [12, 13].

elements.content: The solution of Cu(hfac)2·2H2O (0.1 mmol) in 20 mL of boiling n-heptane was refluxed to remove hydrate water. To the resulting solution cooled to 60 °C was added 5 mL dichloromethane containing 0.1 mmol of NITpPy. The temperature of the reaction was kept at about 60 °C for 15 min, during which a dark blue precipitate appeared, which was filtered off. The filtrate was allowed to cool to room temperature. Two days later, dark blue crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were collected (yield 50%). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C32H20Cu2F24N3O10: C 32.31, H 1.69, N 3.53; found: C 32.53, H 1.78, N 3.35.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of the Complex

The solution of Cu(hfac)2⋅2H2O (0.1 mmol) in 20 mL of boiling n-heptane was refluxed to remove hydrate water. To the resulting solution cooled to 60 °C was added 5 mL dichloromethane containing 0.1 mmol of NITpPy. The temperature of the reaction was kept at about 60 °C for 15 min, during which a dark blue precipitate appeared, which was filtered off. The filtrate was allowed to cool to room temperature. Two days later, dark blue crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were collected (yield 50%). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C32H20Cu2F24N3O10: C 32.31, H 1.69, N 3.53; found: C 32.53, H 1.78, N 3.35.

elements.content: The selected blue crystal with approximate dimensions of 0.41 mm × 0.29 mm × 0.14 mm was mounted on a Bruker Smart AXS CCD with a graphite monochromatic MoK α radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The intensity data were collected at 298(2) K by using a ω and π scan mode in the range of 1.69 ≤ θ ≤ 25.03° with the following index ranges: −23 ≤ h ≤ 22, −20 ≤ k ≤ 19 and 18 ≤ l ≤ 17. A total of 9654 reflections were collected and 3558 were independent (Rint = 0.1459, of which 1164 were considered as observed (I > 2σ(I)). Absorption correction was applied using SADABS program [14].The structure was solved by direct methods with SHELXS-97 [15] and refined by full-matrix least-squares calculations with SHELXL-97 [16]. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. Most of the hydrogen atoms were located at the calculated positions or found from difference Fourier maps (Table 1).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Determination

The selected blue crystal with approximate dimensions of 0.41 mm × 0.29 mm × 0.14 mm was mounted on a Bruker Smart AXS CCD with a graphite monochromatic MoK α radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The intensity data were collected at 298(2) K by using a ω and π scan mode in the range of 1.69 ≤ θ ≤ 25.03° with the following index ranges: -23 ≤ h ≤ 22, -20 ≤ k ≤ 19 and 18 ≤ l ≤ 17. A total of 9654 reflections were collected and 3558 were independent (Rint = 0.1459, of which 1164 were considered as observed (I > 2σ(I)). Absorption correction was applied using SADABS program [14].The structure was solved by direct methods with SHELXS-97 [15] and refined by full-matrix least-squares calculations with SHELXL-97 [16]. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. Most of the hydrogen atoms were located at the calculated positions or found from difference Fourier maps (Table 1).

Molecular structure of 1 is shown in Fig. 1. The complex consists of neutral units Cu(hfac)2 and one NITpPy ligands. Each NITpPy radical links two different copper(II) ions through the oxygen of nitroide group and the pyridyl nitrogen to form a zigzag-like centrosymmetric one-dimensional chain. In the crystal structure of 1, there are two crystallographic independent Cu (Cu1 and Cu2) atoms in the form of Cu(hfac)2. The Cu1 atom has a five-coordinated distorted trigonal bipyramidal environment with four oxygen atoms of two hfac molecules and one pyridyl nitrogen atom. The Cu1–O2 and Cu1–O3 bond lengths are 2.051(8) and 1.945(9) Å, respectively. The Cu1–N2 bond length is 2.014(9) Å. The pyridine ring of nitronyl nitroxide has a dihedral angle of 71.5° with the average plane consisting of equatorial oxygen atoms of the hfac ligands and the Cu1 atom, while the dihedral angle between the ONCNO five member ring is 32.0(4)°. As mentioned above, there is another Cu atom in the unit, which is referred as Cu′(hfac)2. It is noticed that weak coordination bonds are formed between the Cu(II) of Cu(hfac)2 and the oxygen atoms of nitronyl nitroxide with the oxygen atoms occupying the apical positions. The weak Cu2–O1 bond length is 2.50(2) Å and the bond angle of N1–O1–Cu2 is 166(2)°. Here, we could consider NITpPy as a bidentate bridged two different Cu(hfac)2 units. Considering the weak coordination, the coordination environment about the Cu2 ion of Cu′(hfac)2 exhibits a distorted octahedral coordination geometry with O4#2–Cu2–O4 180.0(4)° and O4#2–Cu2–O1 91.7(4)° (#2: −x + 3, −y + 3/2, −z + 1). The two hfac ligands chelated to Cu(II) ion of Cu′(hfac)2 with the Cu2–O4 and Cu2–O5 bond distances of 1.909(5) and 1.903(5) Å, respectively. In the complex 1, Cu–Ohfac bond lengths are slightly shorter than the other copper similar complexes in the previous literature [17]. The ONCNO rings of nitronyl nitroxide are almost perpendicular to the coordinated plane of Cu(hfac)2 with the dihedral angle of 79.55°. As a result, the 1D chain structure was formed through the Cu···O weak coordination bonding and the inter-chain arrangements (Table 2, Fig. 2).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Molecular structure of 1 is shown in Fig. 1. The complex consists of neutral units Cu(hfac)2 and one NITpPy ligands. Each NITpPy radical links two different copper(II) ions through the oxygen of nitroide group and the pyridyl nitrogen to form a zigzag-like centrosymmetric one-dimensional chain. In the crystal structure of 1, there are two crystallographic independent Cu (Cu1 and Cu2) atoms in the form of Cu(hfac)2. The Cu1 atom has a five-coordinated distorted trigonal bipyramidal environment with four oxygen atoms of two hfac molecules and one pyridyl nitrogen atom. The Cu1-O2 and Cu1-O3 bond lengths are 2.051(8) and 1.945(9) Å, respectively. The Cu1-N2 bond length is 2.014(9) Å. The pyridine ring of nitronyl nitroxide has a dihedral angle of 71.5° with the average plane consisting of equatorial oxygen atoms of the hfac ligands and the Cu1 atom, while the dihedral angle between the ONCNO five member ring is 32.0(4)°. As mentioned above, there is another Cu atom in the unit, which is referred as Cu'(hfac)2. It is noticed that weak coordination bonds are formed between the Cu(II) of Cu(hfac)2 and the oxygen atoms of nitronyl nitroxide with the oxygen atoms occupying the apical positions. The weak Cu2-O1 bond length is 2.50(2) Å and the bond angle of N1-O1-Cu2 is 166(2)°. Here, we could consider NITpPy as a bidentate bridged two different Cu(hfac)2 units. Considering the weak coordination, the coordination environment about the Cu2 ion of Cu'(hfac)2 exhibits a distorted octahedral coordination geometry with O4#2-Cu2-O4 180.0(4)° and O4#2-Cu2-O1 91.7(4)° (#2: -x + 3, -y + 3/2, -z + 1). The two hfac ligands chelated to Cu(II) ion of Cu'(hfac)2 with the Cu2-O4 and Cu2-O5 bond distances of 1.909(5) and 1.903(5) Å, respectively. In the complex 1, Cu-Ohfac bond lengths are slightly shorter than the other copper similar complexes in the previous literature [17]. The ONCNO rings of nitronyl nitroxide are almost perpendicular to the coordinated plane of Cu(hfac)2 with the dihedral angle of 79.55°. As a result, the 1D chain structure was formed through the Cu⋅⋅⋅O weak coordination bonding and the inter-chain arrangements (Table 2, Fig. 2).

cln_elements.clean_text:
Preparation of the Complex

The solution of Cu(hfac)2⋅2H2O (0.1 mmol) in 20 mL of boiling n-heptane was refluxed to remove hydrate water. To the resulting solution cooled to 60 °C was added 5 mL dichloromethane containing 0.1 mmol of NITpPy. The temperature of the reaction was kept at about 60 °C for 15 min, during which a dark blue precipitate appeared, which was filtered off. The filtrate was allowed to cool to room temperature. Two days later, dark blue crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were collected (yield 50%). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C32H20Cu2F24N3O10: C 32.31, H 1.69, N 3.53; found: C 32.53, H 1.78, N 3.35.

cln_elements.content: A one-dimensional chain compound was formed by copper (II) hexafluoroacetylacetonate (hfac) and nitroxide radical 2-(4-pyridyl)-4,4,5,5-tetramethyl-imidazoline-1-oxyl-oxide (NITpPy). The product was structurally characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction. [Cu2(hfac)4NITpPy]n crystallizes in the monoclinic C2/c space group with a = 19.70(2), b = 16.834(19), c = 15.274(18) Å, β = 119.073, V = 4427(9) Å3, Z = 4, R = 0.0699 wR2 (all data) = 0.1752. In the compound, two different Cu(hfac)2 units are bridged by NITpPy. The nitrogen atom of pyridine ring is coordinated with Cu(II) ion to afford a three-spin complex. Cu(II) ions of Cu(hfac)2 and the oxygen atoms of nitronyl nitroxide formed weak coordination bonds with the bond length 2.495(8) Å.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A one-dimensional chain compound was formed by copper (II) hexafluoroacetylacetonate (hfac) and nitroxide radical 2-(4-pyridyl)-4,4,5,5-tetramethyl-imidazoline-1-oxyl-oxide (NITpPy). The product was structurally characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction. [Cu2(hfac)4NITpPy]n crystallizes in the monoclinic C2/c space group with a = 19.70(2), b = 16.834(19), c = 15.274(18) Å, β = 119.073, V = 4427(9) Å3, Z = 4, R = 0.0699 wR2 (all data) = 0.1752. In the compound, two different Cu(hfac)2 units are bridged by NITpPy. The nitrogen atom of pyridine ring is coordinated with Cu(II) ion to afford a three-spin complex. Cu(II) ions of Cu(hfac)2 and the oxygen atoms of nitronyl nitroxide formed weak coordination bonds with the bond length 2.495(8) Å.
